newsitem.title: JAPAN: Honda says no plans yet to raise dividend.
newsitem.headline: Honda says no plans yet to raise dividend.

text.p: Honda Motor Co Ltd said on Tuesday it has not decided whether to raise its dividend payment for the 1996/97 business year ending March.

The Nihon Keizai Shimbun financial daily said on Tuesday that Honda is likely to increase its annual dividend payment to 15 yen in 1996/97 from 14 yen the year before, which would be the first increase in seven years.
"We have not decided yet whether to raise the dividend payment for 1996/97," a Honda spokesman told Reuters.
Honda has been paying an annual dividend of 14 yen since 1989/90.

Last August, Honda revised upward its forecast for parent current profit to 120 billion yen in 1996/97, up from 47.18 billion yen a year earlier, mainly helped by robust demand for its recreational vehicle. This would surpass the previous record current profit of 90.5 billion yen set in 1989/90.

"Nikkei's story has had no impact on the stock market today because it's not fresh news. Investors have believed for a long time that Honda would raise its dividend to 15 yen this business year," said Nomura Research analyst Seiji Sugiura.
Honda shares were down 20 yen at 2,710 yen at 0237 GMT.
